articles.headline: Bush Speaks in Defense of Markets
articles.snippet: President Bush defended free enterprise and warned foreign leaders ahead of a weekend meeting not to crush global growth with restrictive new rules.
articles.abstract: President Bush defended free enterprise and warned foreign leaders ahead of a weekend meeting not to crush global growth with restrictive new rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Bush delivered an impassioned defense of free-market capitalism on Thursday, on the eve of an international summit meeting where he is expected to get a tongue-lashing from foreign leaders who view the United States and his administration as responsible for worldwide financial misery.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Chances Dwindle on Bailout Plan for Automakers
articles.snippet: Democratic leaders calling for an aid package to help auto companies conceded that they would face potentially insurmountable opposition in Congress.
articles.abstract: Democratic leaders calling for an aid package to help auto companies conceded that they would face potentially insurmountable opposition in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The prospects of a government rescue for the foundering American automakers dwindled Thursday as Democratic Congressional leaders conceded that they would face potentially insurmountable Republican opposition during a lame-duck session next week.

articles.headline: Accountability Needed With Bailouts
articles.snippet: As the line for handouts grows, the government must gain a better understanding of the problems and a willingness to force painful changes on these troubled industries.
articles.abstract: As the line for handouts grows, the government must gain a better understanding of the problems and a willingness to force painful changes on these troubled industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you are going to hand out rescue packages, it helps to understand how bad the problem is, and to have some grasp of what is needed to fix it.

articles.headline: Lower Gas Prices Don’t Make Americans Feel Rich
articles.snippet: Motorists’ gas bills are down but instead of spending the money, they are putting it in the bank and paying debt.
articles.abstract: Motorists’ gas bills are down but instead of spending the money, they are putting it in the bank and paying debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND  Drivers are breathing a sigh of relief as gasoline prices plunge across the country. Gas below $1.50 a gallon has appeared in a few places in recent days, and the national average has dropped almost in half since July, to $2.18 a gallon.

articles.headline: Many Line Up for Cash, but Bailout Plan Falters
articles.snippet: More than a month after the government began a financial rescue of Wall Street, many of the nation’s financial arteries seem as clogged as they were before.
articles.abstract: More than a month after the government began a financial rescue of Wall Street, many of the nation’s financial arteries seem as clogged as they were before.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the government’s financial rescue enters a new phase, Wall Street and many ordinary Americans are wondering the same thing: Is any of this working?
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Worst May Be Yet to Come for Citigroup
articles.snippet: Once the most valuable financial company in America, Citigroup is experiencing a shrinking share price and work force.
articles.abstract: Once the most valuable financial company in America, Citigroup is experiencing a shrinking share price and work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a year of red ink, a months-long plunge in its share price and a $25 billion government rescue, you might think the worst was over for Citigroup.

articles.headline: Factories Shut, China Workers Are Suffering
articles.snippet: An export slowdown that has been magnified by the global financial crisis is hurting China’s coastal regions.
articles.abstract: An export slowdown that has been magnified by the global financial crisis is hurting China’s coastal regions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANG’AN, China  Wang Denggui, father of three, arrived more than a year ago in the palm-lined streets of this southern town with a single goal: toil in a factory to save for his children’s school tuition.

articles.headline: For Obama and Family, a Personal Transition
articles.snippet: Life for the Obamas has changed forever under the constraints and security of the president-elect’s bubble.
articles.abstract: Life for the Obamas has changed forever under the constraints and security of the president-elect’s bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A couple of weeks ago, Barack Obama headed to the Hyde Park Hair Salon for a trim. He greeted the staff and other customers and plopped down in the same chair in front of the same barber who has cut his hair for the last 14 years.

articles.headline: Militants Turn to Small Bombs in Iraq Attacks
articles.snippet: The portable, furtive bomb known as a “sticky bomb” is fast becoming the device of choice for insurgents.
articles.abstract: The portable, furtive bomb known as a “sticky bomb” is fast becoming the device of choice for insurgents.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  They are usually no bigger than a man’s fist and attached to a magnet or a strip of gummy adhesive  thus the name “obwah lasica” in Arabic, or “sticky bomb.”
articles.byline: By KATHERINE ZOEPF and MUDHAFER AL-HUSAINI

articles.headline: Google Is Taking Questions (Spoken, via iPhone)
articles.snippet: Users of the voice technology can ask any question, ranging from “Where’s the nearest Starbucks?” to “How tall is Mount Everest?”
articles.abstract: Users of the voice technology can ask any question, ranging from “Where’s the nearest Starbucks?” to “How tall is Mount Everest?”
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Pushing ahead in the decades-long effort to get computers to understand human speech, Google researchers have added sophisticated voice recognition technology to the company’s search software for the Apple iPhone.
